posts.cooked: For teams that use metric profiles, what style of bearing blocks are you using? we are thinking about an elevator for this year, but i find it very hard to make a bearing block that is both simple, compact and easy to make. in general, how do you make elevators with the less surface area of the 40x20x2mm extrusion?

posts.name: Halil √ñmer √áelik
posts.cooked: We generally use 50x25x2mm tubes for elevator and redesign vendor‚Äôs COTS elevator blocks. We try to use similar dimension bearings ( OD 19mm bearing instead of 19.05). Changing bearing to bearing dimension was enough for redesign (50mm instead of 50.4mm)

posts.name: Ada
posts.cooked: This year we plan to cnc custom blocks
We have made some custom block with reference to the SDS and WCP ones
3d printing elevator blocks had worked really well for us
did you make it from pla or other material? also, i have seen a model on another thread from 4586, is that the one? and what did that elevator lift?

Pla

The model from the other thread was a rider for a linear slide that had some very high forces applied to it  long arm with a heavy endefactor

The linear slide worked amazing the elevator we havent got much real use out of it so didnt get that stress tested but dont think it would be a problem to endure high stress (with the right design dont expect it to be as small as aluminum block)

posts.name: dasevo
posts.cooked: We‚Äôre milling our bearing blocks from a 3mm duralloy (EN AW 2017) with 11mm OD bearings on M5 bolts. That works just fine, but to get better tolerances, it would be better to turn 5mm axles for the bearings themselves. Last year, we used this design for a telescoping climber, which isn‚Äôt that different in theory.

sorry but I don‚Äôt think I can find it. it was a small fun project me and another student did don‚Äôt know where it is.

but i will add the linear slide 3d print for a reference of how large the it should be if you design it yourself

posts.name: Gal
posts.cooked: We use custom-machined, in-house parts that we designed.
